question: Only on my parent's side. Hi Mark.
Hey.
answer: Saw you at the mall yesterday.

question: Yeah ... Saw you too. So you watching Pearl Jam on MTV tonight?
My mom'll be out of town.
answer: So uh ... Maybe we could uh ...

question: Cool.
... I know, I know--He's just like so FINE ... I'm still like It was amazing, Daph ... I'm like
answer: ... He's not homeless Howard, they just don't say where he lives. Well it's a silly question. Because nobody's homeless in Pleasantville. ... because that's just not what it's like. Listen Howard--it's almost six-thirty. I gotta go.

question: What are you doing?
David, cut it out. Mark Davis is gonna like be here in five minutes.
answer: Well great. The Pleasantville Marathon starts at six thirty.

question: Pleasantville Marathon?
Omigod, I don't be-lieeeeve this! He's gonna like beeeee here!
answer: Weil great. You can watch TV upstairs.

question: Upstairs! Up-staiiirs! There isn't any STEREO!
answer: Oh my God ... Oh my God ...

question: David, stop stressing, you can like-- turn it on normally ...
answer: No you can't, Jen! It's a new TV. It doesn't work without a remote.

question: Oh my God! He's here!
TV repair?
Yeah ...
answer: Well here I am. Holy cow. Look at that. Had a little disaster didn't ya fella.

question: Well here I am. Holy cow. Look at that. Had a little disaster didn't ya fella.
We'll get you fixed up in no time. I know how I'd feel if mine went out. Almost like losing a friend.
answer: You know, we didn't call any TV repair.

question: Hey--who did Muff in take to the masquerade ball when her date came down with the measles?
Right. And how did she dress him?
Remember the one where Bud lost his cousin when he was s'posed to be watching him?
What department store did they go to?
McGinty's.
That's right. Say--why don't you take this remote instead. It's got a little more "Ooomph" in it.
God, David. Just give it to me!
YOU get lost!
What happened?
You--you gotta get us out of here.
Because we don't belong!
answer: Oh sure you do ... "McIntire's Department store" ... "Their father dressed as Prince Charming." That was gorgeous Bud.

question: You know--this is a pretty strange way of showing your appreciation.
answer: Look--we appreciate it. We really do. We just--we want to go home now.

question: But you don't know how long I've been looking for someone like you. I'm very disappointed ... In fact ... I'm starting to get a little upset.
Weil wouldn't you! You look for someone for years ... You pour your heart into it ... This is a privilege you know. I don't think I better talk about this right now.
I don't think we should discuss this until I'm a little bit more composed.
Maybe in a day or so when I'm not so emotional ...
I'm gonna hurl, David. I swear to God.
All that animal fat. I feel it in my pores or something. I still don't see why we're doing this.
answer: We're supposed to be in school.

question: Oh yeah. A Buick. It's swell.
Owns the hardware store.
answer: Okay, now you listen to me! I don't know what's going on but you'd better fix it! I had a date with Mark Davis and I even bought new UNDERWEAR!

question: We just gotta play along for a little while ... till that guy shows up again. Then I'll talk to him and ...
Well, yeah. I'm ... Bud Parker and you're ... um--Mary Sue.
answer: No! I'm not gonna do it! If I don't dress like this for Mom I'm sure as hell not going to do it for you!

question: We don't have a choice Jen. We're stuck until he comes back.
answer: Why can't we just EXPLAIN IT?

question: To who?
answer: Oh God, we are. We're stuck in like "Nerdville". I always knew you'd pay a price for this. I knew you couldn't be hopelessly geekridden for this long without suffering some like, really tragic consequences. ... But it's just not fair. I mean--I'm starting to get really--popular. Debbi Russell transferred to another school and my skin's been great since March and Mark Davis is starting to come around and ...

question: Oh God, we are. We're stuck in like "Nerdville". I always knew you'd pay a price for this. I knew you couldn't be hopelessly geekridden for this long without suffering some like, really tragic consequences. ... But it's just not fair. I mean--I'm starting to get really--popular. Debbi Russell transferred to another school and my skin's been great since March and Mark Davis is starting to come around and ...
answer: What's all the commotion? Where's the cat?

question: Um ... It's ...
answer: Ah, right ... Well--guess I'll see ya later Mary Sue.

question: Who's that?
answer: Biff Martin. Captain of the basketball team.

question: Does he--you know--like "me"?
answer: As a matter of fact he does.

question: Hunh. Those are my friends.
answer: Peggy Jane, Lisa Anne and Betty Jean.

question: Can we do any better?
Okay ...
answer: Last week Class, we discussed the geography of Main Street. This week, we're going to be talking about Elm Street. Can anyone tell me one of the differences between Elm Street and Main Street? Tommy. That's right, Tommy. It's not as long. Also, it only has houses. So the geography of Main Street is different than the geography of Elm Street. Mary Sue.

question: What's outside of Pleasantville?
Outside of Pleasantville ... What's at the end of Main Street?
answer: Oh, Mary Sue. You should know the answer to that. The end of Main Street is just the beginning again.

question: Bud ... Hi ya Bud.
Can I ask you a question?
Well ... If I was to ask your sister ... What I mean is, if I was to go up to Mary Sue ...
answer: Oh God! Are we in that episode?

question: What?
What's the matter?
answer: You want to ask her out tonight, right? And then you want to give her your school pin ...

question: Yeah ... How'd you know?
answer: Lucky guess. Look, Biff ... I don't think it's a real good time for that right now ... What I mean is ... Mary Sue's been a little "different" lately ...

question: She won't go out with me?
answer: I didn't say that. It's just that right now ...

question: I don't know what I'd do if she wouldn't go out with me ...
answer: Look, I'm sure we'll work something out. I'll talk to her or something. Honest. It'll be fine.

question: Look, I'm sure we'll work something out. I'll talk to her or something. Honest. It'll be fine.
One date, Jen--that's all I'm asking. If you don't go out with this guy we could throw their whole universe out of whack.
answer: It's too weird David. This place is giving me the creeps. Did you know all the books are blank?

question: What?
answer: I looked in the library. They got covers with nothing inside them.

question: What were you doing in a library?
answer: I got lost. Oh here ... look at this!

question: JENNIFER!
answer: Just watch. You know why those guys just get cats out of trees? 'Cause nothing burns around here, that's why! They don't need any firemen ...

question: Jen, listen ...
answer: I like--really need a cigarette, too.

question: I'll get us out of here. I really will. But if we don't play along we could alter their whole existence. We may never get home.
answer: You really think anybody's gonna, like, notice if I don't have a chocolate malt with this guy.

question: You sure I'm supposed to wear this? I could like kill a guy with these things.
I've worn some kinky stuff before ...
What do you mean?
answer: They don't notice that kind of thing.

question: So what's the point?
He-llo? I've got like three pounds of underwire here ...
answer: Just go with the program--hunh? I'm late for work.

question: Just go with the program--hunh? I'm late for work.
Sorry ... I had to help my folks and then I couldn't find my hat ...
answer: Oh. I didn't know what to do.

question: What's wrong?
answer: Well--I always wipe down the counter and then you set out the napkins and glasses and then I make the french fries ...

question: Yeah ...
answer: But you didn't come so I kept on wiping.

question: I'm sorry. You know, if this ever happens again, you can make the fries even if I haven't put out the napkins yet.
Peppermint shake, chocolate soda, two orders of fries and a split?
What?
answer: Well, usually I put out the burger and then you finish with the lettuce ...

question: Listen to me! Do you have the lettuce?
Have you cooked the burgers?
I sure am glad you said you'd come out with me tonight Mary Sue.
answer: Well "gee whizz" Biff. I sure am glad you asked me.

question: I don't know if I ever said this to you before, but, well ... I think you're just about the keenest girl in the whole school ...
Oh yeah.
answer: Gosh. I hardly know what to say.

question: Oh, I dunno Bud. Guess I'll have my usual cheeseburger and a cherry coke.
answer: Oh, I dunno Bud. Guess I'll just have a salad and an Evian Water. Cheeseburger it is.

question: See the whole time we were in civics together, I really wanted to sit next to you--but you were always sitting between Peggy Jane and Lisa Anne. ... And you always seemed so smart and everything. Like that report you did on "Our Town Hall." Gosh. I didn't know what I'd talk to you about.
answer: Well, sometimes talking's over-rated. Don't you think?

question: Hunh? Oh, right ... So I know I haven't been steady with anybody, but I just don't want to rush it. You don't want to make a mistake with something that important.
I mean, there's kids that are even holding hands already but I figure there's plenty of time for that kind of thing later on. Don't you?
answer: Oh you bet. Will you excuse me for a sec? Jesus Chirist ... I don't think he knows how.

question: Gee whiz "Bud", what could we possibly need when we have each other?
answer: Anyhow ... I really wanted to come over and sit next to you in civics but ...

question: You want to get out of here?
You wanna get out of here? You wanna leave?
... Lover's Lane.
Sure is pretty.
To be honest Mary Sue. I didn't think you'd want to come here until we'd been pinned for a little while.
answer: Oh, Biff. You can "pin" me any time you want to. Or maybe I should just "pin" you.

question: I think I better go home now Mary Sue ...
I think ... I might be ill ... I think something's happening to me.
It is?
Do you want some more cookies?
How 'bout some Marshmallow Rice Squares?
Now who could that be.
Oh hi!
answer: Hi there. You took off so quick. I wasn't sure if you were okay.

question: Oh, yeah. Sorry. I'm fine. I just ... Had to get home early.
Yeah ...
answer: You know how when we close up, I close the register, then you lower the shades, then I turn out the lights, then we both lock the doors.

question: Yeah ...
answer: Well you weren't around this time so I did the whole thing myself. Not only that, I didn't even do it in the same order. First I lowered the shades, then I closed the register. Oh, hello Betty.

question: You have no right to do this.
answer: Well if I don't who will?

question: They're happy like this.
answer: David, nobody's happy in a Poodle skirt and a sweater set. You like all this don't you? I mean, you don't think it's just like dorky or funny or something ... you really like it. Oh God! I am just so personally horrified right now ...

question: I just don't think we have the right to ...
answer: David, let me tell you something. These people don't want to be geeks. They want to be "attractive." They've got a lot of potential, they just don't know any better.

question: They don't have that kind of potential.
answer: Um--hello? You want to like take a look?

question: Really? It seems so fattening. Two cheeseburgers, two cherry cokes.
Look. I thought we talked about this, I thought we said ...
C'mere. What did you say?
answer: Well ... I'm not sure I see the point anymore.

question: What are you talking about! You make hamburgers! That is the point!
answer: No I know ... I know I do ... But it's always the same, you know? Grill the bun, flip the meat, melt the cheese ... It never changes. It never gets any better or worse ...

question: Just listen to me ...
answer: ... Like the other night, when I closed up by myself. That was different ...

question: Forget about that!
answer: Oh ... Okay. ... But I really liked it.

question: Look, you can't always like what you do. Sometimes you just do it because it's your job. And even if you don't like it, you just gotta do it anyway.
So they can have their hamburgers!
answer: You know what I really like?

question: ... What's that?
answer: Christmastime. See every year on Dec 3, I get to paint the Christmas decorations in the window. And every year, I get to paint a different thing ... One year it's the North Pole. The next I do Santa's workshop. Here I'll show you.

question: Wow ... That's pretty good ...
answer: Thanks. But this morning I was thinking about it and I realized that I looked forward to it all year. And then I thought "Gee. That seems awfully silly. That seems like an awfully long time to be waiting for just one moment, don't you think?" Well don't you?

question: I think you should try not to think about this anymore.
Yeah.
answer: Oh. Okay. I'll try that then.

question: Uh ... Seven hearts. Mary Sue?
Can I ask you a question?
What goes on up at Lover's Lane?
Well, you hear all these things lately. You know--kids spending so much time up there ... Is it holding hands? That kind of thing?
What?
No. I want to know.
Ah. What's sex?
answer: You sure you want to know this?

question: Yes.
answer: Okay. You see Mom ... When two people like each other very much ... You okay?

question: Yes ... It's just that ...
Well ... ... Your father would never do anything like that.
answer: Oh. Hmm ... Well, Mom ... there's ways to "enjoy" yourself without Dad.

question: That was sure swell ...
I baked you my oatmeal cookies.
answer: Oh, no ... You baked those for Whitey.

question: No. I baked them for you.
answer: No. You baked them for Whitey.

question: No. I baked them for you.
I had nothing to do with that fire.
Not directly anyhow ...
Um ... They like wanna ask you a question ... I didn't know how to handle it. So ...
Sure. How you doin?
answer: How'd you know about the fire?

question: What?
answer: How'd you know how to put it out and all?

question: Well--where I used to live ... That's just what firemen did.
Um ... Outside of Pleasantville.
Look it doesn't matter. It's not important.
It's really not important.
Well ... There are some places where the road doesn't go in a circle. There are some places where it keeps on going.
I thought the books were blank?
answer: They were. Okay look, this like--wasn't my fault. They asked me what it was about and I like didn't remember 'cause we had it back in tenth grade, But I told them what I DID remember, and the next thing I knew the pages had filled in.

question: The pages filled in?
answer: But like only up to the part about the raft, because I didn't read any farther.

question: Want some bridge mix?
Betty's making some pineapple kabobs ...
answer: I'm fine--but thank you. George, you're probably wondering why I asked if I could come over today ... I'm sure you've noticed the same things we all have--certain "changes" going on in the town. You know what I mean by "changes"?

question: "Changes."
answer: "Changes." And it's not just the fire or big stuff like that. It's little things. Did you hear about Bill Miller?

question: No. What?
answer: Wife wants him to get one of those new beds.

question: One of those ... big beds? Oh my gosh. What's he gonna to do?
answer: I really don't know. Ben Miller's son just quit his job as a boxboy at the market.

question: ... How?
answer: Said he didn't want to do it anymore. Just took off his apron in the middle of an order. Mrs. Thompson had her groceries spread all over the counter ... Took 'em four hours to sort the whole thing out.

question: Holy cow.
Oh well ...
answer: No. They do. And it isn't just 'cause you're a great bowler ... They respect you ...

question: Thank you very much.
answer: And it's important for them to see someone they respect, stand up for what's right. If you love a place, you can't sit around and watch this kind of thing happen to it.

question: No. Of course not.
answer: And that's why I want you to be on the Pleasantville Chamber of Commerce.

question: Oh my Gosh. I hardly know what to say.
answer: Why don't you start by saying "yes," and then getting me one of those swell pineapple kabobs.

question: I'll get her. Are you okay? Are you alright?
answer: What am I going to do?

question: It's okay. It's alright.
answer: I can't go out there. How can I go out there? Look at me ...

question: Have you got any make up?
Okay--first we'll dry you out a little.
Looks just like it did.
answer: And they won't be able to tell?

question: No ... They won't be able to tell. Wait.
It's fine.
Sure.
Hi.
I brought you something ... From the library. It's an art book.
Open it. I just thought since you liked painting it might help to ...
What's wrong?
answer: I'll never be able to do that.

question: Oh, well--you're just starting out. I mean, you can't do it ...
answer: No, that's not it. Where am I going to see colors like that? Must be awfully lucky to see colors like that. I bet they don't even know how lucky they are.

question: Hi.

Look, I probably shouldn't be asking you this--not knowing you that well and all ... It's just that my folks are gonna stay home and they said I could use their car. ... You want to go out with me tonight?
... Lover's Lane? Sorry ... "Oh when the Saints ... Go Marching in ..."
... Hi.
answer: Well c'mere, young fella. You know I've been thinkin' ... I might have been a little "hasty" the other day when you asked to come home--just took me by such surprise, ya know--ha ha ... So even though I can't make any promises, well--I figured if you asked me real nice--I might just be willing to talk about it again.

question: I can't.
Talk about it. Right now, I mean. I got to ... um ...
answer: Bud--I thought you wanted to come home.

question: Oh ... I do. Yeah. It's just that I told my "dad" I'd clean out the rain gutters and Mr. Johnson wanted me to ... to change the tape in the register ...
answer: I'll be honest with you Bud. I'm getting sorta concerned about what I'm seeing in some of these re-runs ...

question: Re-runs?
answer: Like when Margaret Henderson makes her cookies for Whitey. ... Those aren't your cookies Bud.

question: Oh, I know they're not. But I mean-- they're just "cookies" after all ...

Well they're not just cookies. I mean, they're great cookies ... Look, I'd love to get into this whole thing but I'm really running late. Why don't we hook up tomorrow? Terrific. I'll talk to you then.
Nothing.
Listen ... You're reading?
answer: Yeah. Can't believe you started such a dorky fad. D.H. Lawrence. You ever heard of him?

question: ... Yeah.
answer: Seemed kinda sexy. Look. I read 35 pages.

question: That's great.
Well ... I just ... Can I ask you a question?
Remember when you told me that Lisa Rosenberg liked me?
Well--did she really like me or were you just making that up.
You weren't playing a joke? She woulda gone out with me?
answer: Gone out with you. She woulda like rearranged your tonsils.

question: Wow.
answer: Can I ask you a question?

question: Yes.
answer: How come I'm still in black and white?

question: What?
answer: Well I've had like ten times as much sex as these girls and I'm still like this. They have one hour in the back of a car and suddenly they're in technicolor.

question: Oh, I don't know. Maybe ... ... it's not just the sex ...
answer: What? No, it's not just the sex, is it?

question: We're closed right now ... Oh, hi ...
No, no ... Come on in.
Thanks. I was just trying to do one of these "still lifes." Having kind of a tough time.
Well ... Here's what it's s'posed to look like.
Here. Look at this.
Bud brought it to me.
Here's my favorite. What do you think? Isn't it great how she's resting like that?
What?
No she's not.
Wait ...
It's alright. It's alright. Let me see.
Hunh.
What are you doing?
So.
Oh. I can't.
I'm busy.
Mmmmgh.
answer: Do they have those ... Where you come from?

question: Yeah ... I guess. I don't know.
answer: You don't know? So what's it like?

question: What?
Oh. don't know ... It's different.
Well it's louder ... And scarier I guess ... And ... and a lot more dangerous ...
answer: Sounds fantastic. You know some kids came up here the other night to go swimming--took off all their clothes. Do they have an Ocean? I've heard about the ocean.

question: Yeah.
Well it's big. And it's blue ... ... It's really really blue.
answer: Mmmm. Boy. It's hot up here. You want some berries?

question: Hunh?
answer: I picked them myself. They grow wild up here. Mmm. So sweet.

question: They just grow like that?
answer: Oh yeah. There's a lot of stuff. Currants and strawberries ... Here. I'll show you. Here. Go on. Try it.

question: What is that? What's going on?
Real rain?
answer: Yeah ... You don't have rain either? Right. Of course you don't ...

question: What do we do?
answer: We'll just put up the top.

question: What top?
answer: It's fine. Come on. It's alright. There's nothing to be afraid of.

question: Honey, I'm home ... Where's my dinner? Where's my dinner ... Where's my DINNER ... Where's my DINNER! ... WHERE'S MY DINNER! WHERE'S MY DINNER! Where's my dinner?
answer: What happened? Are you alright? What is it?

question: Rain.
answer: Real rain? Oh my God ... ... We had no idea. Burt was rolling a 250 and ... Are you alright? What happened?

question: Well, I ... I came home like I always do, And I came in the front door. And I took off my coat. And I put down my briefcase and I said "Honey. I'm home." ... Only no one was there. So I went into the kitchen and I yelled it again. "Honey--I'm home." But there was no one there either. No wife. No lights. No dinner. So I went to the oven--you know-- because I thought maybe she had made me one of those "TV dinners ..." But she hadn't. She was gone.
You can't go out there.
answer: But I really should get home.

question: But you can't go out there.
answer: Sounds nice ... Once you get used to it.

question: Yeah. It does.
I told you where I was.
I got caught in the storm. You were gone all night too.
answer: I was in a bowling-alley. Look. Let's just forget about it. Let's just go to the meeting and ...

question: I told you, George. I'm not going.
No I'm not. Look at me George. That meeting's not for me. Look at my face.
answer: It's fine. You'll put on some make up and ...

question: I don't want to put on some make up ...
answer: It goes away ... It'll go away.

question: I don't want it to go away.
answer: Okay--now you listen to me ... You're gonna come to this meeting and you're gonna put on this make up, and you're gonna come home at six o'clock every night and have dinner ready on this table.

question: No I'm not sweetie. ... There's a meatloaf in the fridge. You just put it in the oven and turn this little knob up to three-fifty. If you put the pie in forty minutes later, it'll be hot in time for dessert. I made a couple of lunches for you and put them in brown paper bags ... I'm gonna go now.
I'm gonna go now.
answer: Betty, don't go out there like that! They'll see you! They'll SEE you! Betty, come back here!

question: I got you something.
answer: It's beautiful. Where'd you get it?

question: It was a prop for the school play ...
Hey Bud, how come you're not at the town meeting right now?
answer: No reason. How come you're not?

question: Oh. We're s'posed to go out and let everybody know about it. See. No reason hunh ... See I thought maybe it was cause you were too busy entertaining your colored girlfriend.
answer: Why don't you guys just get the hell out of here.

question: Oh, okay, Bud. We'll do that. You know Margaret, you can come over and bake those Oatmeal cookies for me anytime you want to.
answer: It's fine ... It doesn't mean anything.

question: Bud ... I want a word with you ...
What the hell do you think you're doing!
What do I MEAN! You think this is a toy? You think it's your own little goddamn coloring book ...
A deluge doesn't just "happen." Bolts of lightning don't just "happen" ... You burned down an ELM tree for Christ's sake ...
answer: I had nothing to do with that.

question: Oh. I'm sorry--refresh my memory. What episode does the orgy happen in, again?
It was a gift Bud. It was so special. You liked these things as much as I did, remember
answer: ... Only if they mean it. I didn't do anything wrong.

question: Oh no? Let me show you something! "YOU DON'T DESERVE THIS PLACE." Where's the remote control I gave you?
Because you're coming home. I'm gonna put this place back the way it was.
EXCUSE ME?
answer: I'm sorry ... I can't let you do that.

question: JUST GIMME THE GODDAMN REMOTE! OW!
You're not going anywhere. You're gonna get that remote and you're gonna come home and we're gonna make everybody HAPPY AGAIN!!! Don't make me get rough with you! I can get awfully fucking rough!
answer: Come on! COME ON! Get out of here! Are you alright? What? Come on. Oh my God. Are you alright? Are you okay?

question: Maybe I have an idea.
Yes I did.
answer: Do you know that it's illegal?

question: Yes I do.
Because anybody should be able to paint in whatever color they want.
answer: You're not allowed to do this! I could arrest you for this.

question: Still doesn't make it right.
answer: Dan! Arrest them! What do you mean!? You put handcuffs on them and you take them to the police station.

question: C'mere, Dan. I'll help you. I thought it might be you.
I am actually ... Glad to see you've finally shown your true colors.
answer: Okay, let's cut the shit and get right to it. Where's that remote control?

question: Why?
Why don't you just take me back without it?
answer: Oh. You're a smart little bastard aren't you? It's kind of like a restricted ticket. You gotta leave the same way you came.

question: So ... I guess as long as I'm here, all sorts of things could happen to this place. We could have pink lawns and blue trees ...
I'm sorry. I can't do that.
answer: I don't know what went wrong. You answered every question. You knew every detail. The senior Prom ... McIntire's Department Store. We had all the same warm memories

question: They weren't my memories. I borrowed them. It's no good when you borrow them.
answer: How long do you think you've been here?

question: I don't know ... Three, four weeks.
answer: Much less than that. An hour and a half. See--and this is really great-- the show was on for what--half an hour a week? So that means for every week that goes by in Pleasantville, only half an hour goes by in the real world. Now Buddy, you're going on trial tomorrow. And if they find you guilty, you're gonna be stuck here forever. Well, not forever--lemme think ... Five year sentence ... Carry the three ... That comes out to ... sixteen and a half centuries, and that's rounding down.

question: I'm going on trial tomorrow?
answer: This is TV pal. They don't fool around.

question: There's worse places.
answer: Oh sure. For the first hundred years. Then it starts to get a little monotonous. Sleep well.

question: Bud Parker and William Johnson, you have been charged with desecration of a public building and the intentional use of prohibited paint colors in violation of the Pleasantville Code of Conduct and laws of common decency. Do you admit that on the night of May 1, you did consciously and willfully apply the following FORBIDDEN colors to the Pleasantville Town Hall
answer: Um ... Yes I do. Where's our lawyer?

question: We prefer to keep these proceedings as "pleasant" as possible. I don't think a lawyer will be necessary. Do you further admit that this was done surreptitiously and under the cover of darkness?
Good. Do you further admit that this unnatural depiction occurred in full public view where it was accessible to, and in plain sight of, minor children?
I think I've got something to say.

I think I know why you're doing this. I mean, I understand why you're doing this. I used to feel the same way. I used to want this place to stay just the way it was. I never wanted it to change ... But nothing stays the same. You get things, and you lose things, and that's the good part and the bad part--but you can't have a good part without a bad part. It's like the basketball team.

Sure. Everybody's upset because they're not winning anymore--but just think how it would feel if all of a sudden they do win. Wouldn't it feel better than when they used to win all the time? See, I know you want it to stay "Pleasant" but there are so many things that are so much better
I thought I was allowed to defend myself.
I'm not lying ... Here I'll show you. Mr. Simpson ...
